speaker: PANDARUS
text_entry: ACT I

speaker: PANDARUS
text_entry: SCENE I. DUKE ORSINO's palace.

speaker: PANDARUS
text_entry: Enter DUKE ORSINO, CURIO, and other Lords; Musicians attending

speaker: DUKE ORSINO
text_entry: If music be the food of love, play on;

speaker: DUKE ORSINO
text_entry: Give me excess of it, that, surfeiting,

speaker: DUKE ORSINO
text_entry: The appetite may sicken, and so die.

speaker: DUKE ORSINO
text_entry: That strain again! it had a dying fall:

speaker: DUKE ORSINO
text_entry: O, it came o'er my ear like the sweet sound,

speaker: DUKE ORSINO
text_entry: That breathes upon a bank of violets,

speaker: DUKE ORSINO
text_entry: Stealing and giving odour! Enough; no more:

speaker: DUKE ORSINO
text_entry: 'Tis not so sweet now as it was before.

speaker: DUKE ORSINO
text_entry: O spirit of love! how quick and fresh art thou,

speaker: DUKE ORSINO
text_entry: That, notwithstanding thy capacity

speaker: DUKE ORSINO
text_entry: Receiveth as the sea, nought enters there,

speaker: DUKE ORSINO
text_entry: Of what validity and pitch soe'er,

speaker: DUKE ORSINO
text_entry: But falls into abatement and low price,

speaker: DUKE ORSINO
text_entry: Even in a minute: so full of shapes is fancy

speaker: DUKE ORSINO
text_entry: That it alone is high fantastical.

speaker: CURIO
text_entry: Will you go hunt, my lord?

speaker: DUKE ORSINO
text_entry: What, Curio?

speaker: CURIO
text_entry: The hart.

speaker: DUKE ORSINO
text_entry: Why, so I do, the noblest that I have:

speaker: DUKE ORSINO
text_entry: O, when mine eyes did see Olivia first,

speaker: DUKE ORSINO
text_entry: Methought she purged the air of pestilence!

speaker: DUKE ORSINO
text_entry: That instant was I turn'd into a hart;

speaker: DUKE ORSINO
text_entry: And my desires, like fell and cruel hounds,

speaker: DUKE ORSINO
text_entry: E'er since pursue me.

speaker: DUKE ORSINO
text_entry: Enter VALENTINE

speaker: DUKE ORSINO
text_entry: How now! what news from her?

speaker: VALENTINE
text_entry: So please my lord, I might not be admitted;

speaker: VALENTINE
text_entry: But from her handmaid do return this answer:

speaker: VALENTINE
text_entry: The element itself, till seven years' heat,

speaker: VALENTINE
text_entry: Shall not behold her face at ample view;

speaker: VALENTINE
text_entry: But, like a cloistress, she will veiled walk

speaker: VALENTINE
text_entry: And water once a day her chamber round

speaker: VALENTINE
text_entry: With eye-offending brine: all this to season

speaker: VALENTINE
text_entry: A brother's dead love, which she would keep fresh

speaker: VALENTINE
text_entry: And lasting in her sad remembrance.

speaker: DUKE ORSINO
text_entry: O, she that hath a heart of that fine frame

speaker: DUKE ORSINO
text_entry: To pay this debt of love but to a brother,

speaker: DUKE ORSINO
text_entry: How will she love, when the rich golden shaft

speaker: DUKE ORSINO
text_entry: Hath kill'd the flock of all affections else

speaker: DUKE ORSINO
text_entry: That live in her; when liver, brain and heart,

speaker: DUKE ORSINO
text_entry: These sovereign thrones, are all supplied, and fill'd

speaker: DUKE ORSINO
text_entry: Her sweet perfections with one self king!

speaker: DUKE ORSINO
text_entry: Away before me to sweet beds of flowers:

speaker: DUKE ORSINO
text_entry: Love-thoughts lie rich when canopied with bowers.

speaker: DUKE ORSINO
text_entry: Exeunt

speaker: DUKE ORSINO
text_entry: SCENE II. The sea-coast.

speaker: DUKE ORSINO
text_entry: Enter VIOLA, a Captain, and Sailors

speaker: VIOLA
text_entry: What country, friends, is this?

speaker: Captain
text_entry: This is Illyria, lady.

speaker: VIOLA
text_entry: And what should I do in Illyria?

speaker: VIOLA
text_entry: My brother he is in Elysium.

speaker: VIOLA
text_entry: Perchance he is not drown'd: what think you, sailors?

speaker: Captain
text_entry: It is perchance that you yourself were saved.

speaker: VIOLA
text_entry: O my poor brother! and so perchance may he be.

speaker: Captain
text_entry: True, madam: and, to comfort you with chance,

speaker: Captain
text_entry: Assure yourself, after our ship did split,

speaker: Captain
text_entry: When you and those poor number saved with you

speaker: Captain
text_entry: Hung on our driving boat, I saw your brother,

speaker: Captain
text_entry: Most provident in peril, bind himself,

speaker: Captain
text_entry: Courage and hope both teaching him the practise,

speaker: Captain
text_entry: To a strong mast that lived upon the sea;

speaker: Captain
text_entry: Where, like Arion on the dolphin's back,

speaker: Captain
text_entry: I saw him hold acquaintance with the waves

speaker: Captain
text_entry: So long as I could see.

speaker: VIOLA
text_entry: For saying so, there's gold:

speaker: VIOLA
text_entry: Mine own escape unfoldeth to my hope,

speaker: VIOLA
text_entry: Whereto thy speech serves for authority,

speaker: VIOLA
text_entry: The like of him. Know'st thou this country?

speaker: Captain
text_entry: Ay, madam, well; for I was bred and born

speaker: Captain
text_entry: Not three hours' travel from this very place.

speaker: VIOLA
text_entry: Who governs here?

speaker: Captain
text_entry: A noble duke, in nature as in name.

speaker: VIOLA
text_entry: What is the name?

speaker: Captain
text_entry: Orsino.

speaker: VIOLA
text_entry: Orsino! I have heard my father name him:

speaker: VIOLA
text_entry: He was a bachelor then.

speaker: Captain
text_entry: And so is now, or was so very late;

speaker: Captain
text_entry: For but a month ago I went from hence,

speaker: Captain
text_entry: And then 'twas fresh in murmur,--as, you know,

speaker: Captain
text_entry: What great ones do the less will prattle of,--

speaker: Captain
text_entry: That he did seek the love of fair Olivia.

speaker: VIOLA
text_entry: What's she?

speaker: Captain
text_entry: A virtuous maid, the daughter of a count

speaker: Captain
text_entry: That died some twelvemonth since, then leaving her

speaker: Captain
text_entry: In the protection of his son, her brother,

speaker: Captain
text_entry: Who shortly also died: for whose dear love,

speaker: Captain
text_entry: They say, she hath abjured the company

speaker: Captain
text_entry: And sight of men.

speaker: VIOLA
text_entry: O that I served that lady

speaker: VIOLA
text_entry: And might not be delivered to the world,

speaker: VIOLA
text_entry: Till I had made mine own occasion mellow,

speaker: VIOLA
text_entry: What my estate is!

speaker: Captain
text_entry: That were hard to compass;

speaker: Captain
text_entry: Because she will admit no kind of suit,

speaker: Captain
text_entry: No, not the duke's.

speaker: VIOLA
text_entry: There is a fair behavior in thee, captain;

speaker: VIOLA
text_entry: And though that nature with a beauteous wall

speaker: VIOLA
text_entry: Doth oft close in pollution, yet of thee

speaker: VIOLA
text_entry: I will believe thou hast a mind that suits

speaker: VIOLA
text_entry: With this thy fair and outward character.

speaker: VIOLA
text_entry: I prithee, and I'll pay thee bounteously,

speaker: VIOLA
text_entry: Conceal me what I am, and be my aid

speaker: VIOLA
text_entry: For such disguise as haply shall become

speaker: VIOLA
text_entry: The form of my intent. I'll serve this duke:

speaker: VIOLA
text_entry: Thou shall present me as an eunuch to him:

speaker: VIOLA
text_entry: It may be worth thy pains; for I can sing

speaker: VIOLA
text_entry: And speak to him in many sorts of music

speaker: VIOLA
text_entry: That will allow me very worth his service.

speaker: VIOLA
text_entry: What else may hap to time I will commit;

speaker: VIOLA
text_entry: Only shape thou thy silence to my wit.

speaker: Captain
text_entry: Be you his eunuch, and your mute I'll be:

speaker: Captain
text_entry: When my tongue blabs, then let mine eyes not see.

speaker: VIOLA
text_entry: I thank thee: lead me on.

speaker: VIOLA
text_entry: Exeunt

speaker: VIOLA
text_entry: SCENE III. OLIVIA'S house.

speaker: VIOLA
text_entry: Enter SIR TOBY BELCH and MARIA

speaker: SIR TOBY BELCH
text_entry: What a plague means my niece, to take the death of

speaker: SIR TOBY BELCH
text_entry: her brother thus? I am sure care's an enemy to life.

speaker: MARIA
text_entry: By my troth, Sir Toby, you must come in earlier o'

speaker: MARIA
text_entry: nights: your cousin, my lady, takes great

speaker: MARIA
text_entry: exceptions to your ill hours.

speaker: SIR TOBY BELCH
text_entry: Why, let her except, before excepted.

speaker: MARIA
text_entry: Ay, but you must confine yourself within the modest

speaker: MARIA
text_entry: limits of order.

speaker: SIR TOBY BELCH
text_entry: Confine! I'll confine myself no finer than I am:

speaker: SIR TOBY BELCH
text_entry: these clothes are good enough to drink in; and so be

speaker: SIR TOBY BELCH
text_entry: these boots too: an they be not, let them hang

speaker: SIR TOBY BELCH
text_entry: themselves in their own straps.

speaker: MARIA
text_entry: That quaffing and drinking will undo you: I heard

speaker: MARIA
text_entry: my lady talk of it yesterday; and of a foolish

speaker: MARIA
text_entry: knight that you brought in one night here to be her wooer.

speaker: SIR TOBY BELCH
text_entry: Who, Sir Andrew Aguecheek?

speaker: MARIA
text_entry: Ay, he.

speaker: SIR TOBY BELCH
text_entry: He's as tall a man as any's in Illyria.

speaker: MARIA
text_entry: What's that to the purpose?

speaker: SIR TOBY BELCH
text_entry: Why, he has three thousand ducats a year.

speaker: MARIA
text_entry: Ay, but he'll have but a year in all these ducats:

speaker: MARIA
text_entry: he's a very fool and a prodigal.

speaker: SIR TOBY BELCH
text_entry: Fie, that you'll say so! he plays o' the

speaker: SIR TOBY BELCH
text_entry: viol-de-gamboys, and speaks three or four languages

speaker: SIR TOBY BELCH
text_entry: word for word without book, and hath all the good

speaker: SIR TOBY BELCH
text_entry: gifts of nature.

speaker: MARIA
text_entry: He hath indeed, almost natural: for besides that

speaker: MARIA
text_entry: he's a fool, he's a great quarreller: and but that

speaker: MARIA
text_entry: he hath the gift of a coward to allay the gust he

speaker: MARIA
text_entry: hath in quarrelling, 'tis thought among the prudent

speaker: MARIA
text_entry: he would quickly have the gift of a grave.

speaker: SIR TOBY BELCH
text_entry: By this hand, they are scoundrels and subtractors

speaker: SIR TOBY BELCH
text_entry: that say so of him. Who are they?

speaker: MARIA
text_entry: They that add, moreover, he's drunk nightly in your company.

speaker: SIR TOBY BELCH
text_entry: With drinking healths to my niece: I'll drink to

speaker: SIR TOBY BELCH
text_entry: her as long as there is a passage in my throat and

speaker: SIR TOBY BELCH
text_entry: drink in Illyria: he's a coward and a coystrill

speaker: SIR TOBY BELCH
text_entry: that will not drink to my niece till his brains turn

speaker: SIR TOBY BELCH
text_entry: o' the toe like a parish-top. What, wench!

speaker: SIR TOBY BELCH
text_entry: Castiliano vulgo! for here comes Sir Andrew Agueface.

speaker: SIR TOBY BELCH
text_entry: Enter SIR ANDREW

speaker: SIR ANDREW
text_entry: Sir Toby Belch! how now, Sir Toby Belch!

speaker: SIR TOBY BELCH
text_entry: Sweet Sir Andrew!

speaker: SIR ANDREW
text_entry: Bless you, fair shrew.

speaker: MARIA
text_entry: And you too, sir.

speaker: SIR TOBY BELCH
text_entry: Accost, Sir Andrew, accost.

speaker: SIR ANDREW
text_entry: What's that?

speaker: SIR TOBY BELCH
text_entry: My niece's chambermaid.

speaker: SIR ANDREW
text_entry: Good Mistress Accost, I desire better acquaintance.

speaker: MARIA
text_entry: My name is Mary, sir.

speaker: SIR ANDREW
text_entry: Good Mistress Mary Accost,--

speaker: SIR TOBY BELCH
text_entry: You mistake, knight; 'accost' is front her, board

speaker: SIR TOBY BELCH
text_entry: her, woo her, assail her.

speaker: SIR ANDREW
text_entry: By my troth, I would not undertake her in this

speaker: SIR ANDREW
text_entry: company. Is that the meaning of 'accost'?

speaker: MARIA
text_entry: Fare you well, gentlemen.

speaker: SIR TOBY BELCH
text_entry: An thou let part so, Sir Andrew, would thou mightst

speaker: SIR TOBY BELCH
text_entry: never draw sword again.

speaker: SIR ANDREW
text_entry: An you part so, mistress, I would I might never

speaker: SIR ANDREW
text_entry: draw sword again. Fair lady, do you think you have

speaker: SIR ANDREW
text_entry: fools in hand?

speaker: MARIA
text_entry: Sir, I have not you by the hand.

speaker: SIR ANDREW
text_entry: Marry, but you shall have; and here's my hand.

speaker: MARIA
text_entry: Now, sir, 'thought is free:' I pray you, bring

speaker: MARIA
text_entry: your hand to the buttery-bar and let it drink.

speaker: SIR ANDREW
text_entry: Wherefore, sweet-heart? what's your metaphor?

speaker: MARIA
text_entry: It's dry, sir.

speaker: SIR ANDREW
text_entry: Why, I think so: I am not such an ass but I can

speaker: SIR ANDREW
text_entry: keep my hand dry. But what's your jest?

speaker: MARIA
text_entry: A dry jest, sir.

speaker: SIR ANDREW
text_entry: Are you full of them?

speaker: MARIA
text_entry: Ay, sir, I have them at my fingers' ends: marry,

speaker: MARIA
text_entry: now I let go your hand, I am barren.

speaker: MARIA
text_entry: Exit

speaker: SIR TOBY BELCH
text_entry: O knight thou lackest a cup of canary: when did I

speaker: SIR TOBY BELCH
text_entry: see thee so put down?

speaker: SIR ANDREW
text_entry: Never in your life, I think; unless you see canary

speaker: SIR ANDREW
text_entry: put me down. Methinks sometimes I have no more wit

speaker: SIR ANDREW
text_entry: than a Christian or an ordinary man has: but I am a

speaker: SIR ANDREW
text_entry: great eater of beef and I believe that does harm to my wit.

speaker: SIR TOBY BELCH
text_entry: No question.

speaker: SIR ANDREW
text_entry: An I thought that, I'ld forswear it. I'll ride home

speaker: SIR ANDREW
text_entry: to-morrow, Sir Toby.

speaker: SIR TOBY BELCH
text_entry: Pourquoi, my dear knight?

speaker: SIR ANDREW
text_entry: What is 'Pourquoi'? do or not do? I would I had

speaker: SIR ANDREW
text_entry: bestowed that time in the tongues that I have in

speaker: SIR ANDREW
text_entry: fencing, dancing and bear-baiting: O, had I but

speaker: SIR ANDREW
text_entry: followed the arts!

speaker: SIR TOBY BELCH
text_entry: Then hadst thou had an excellent head of hair.

speaker: SIR ANDREW
text_entry: Why, would that have mended my hair?

speaker: SIR TOBY BELCH
text_entry: Past question; for thou seest it will not curl by nature.

speaker: SIR ANDREW
text_entry: But it becomes me well enough, does't not?

speaker: SIR TOBY BELCH
text_entry: Excellent; it hangs like flax on a distaff; and I

speaker: SIR TOBY BELCH
text_entry: hope to see a housewife take thee between her legs

speaker: SIR TOBY BELCH
text_entry: and spin it off.

speaker: SIR ANDREW
text_entry: Faith, I'll home to-morrow, Sir Toby: your niece

speaker: SIR ANDREW
text_entry: will not be seen; or if she be, it's four to one

speaker: SIR ANDREW
text_entry: she'll none of me: the count himself here hard by woos her.

speaker: SIR TOBY BELCH
text_entry: She'll none o' the count: she'll not match above

speaker: SIR TOBY BELCH
text_entry: her degree, neither in estate, years, nor wit; I

speaker: SIR TOBY BELCH
text_entry: have heard her swear't. Tut, there's life in't,

speaker: SIR TOBY BELCH
text_entry: man.

speaker: SIR ANDREW
text_entry: I'll stay a month longer. I am a fellow o' the

speaker: SIR ANDREW
text_entry: strangest mind i' the world; I delight in masques

speaker: SIR ANDREW
text_entry: and revels sometimes altogether.

speaker: SIR TOBY BELCH
text_entry: Art thou good at these kickshawses, knight?

speaker: SIR ANDREW
text_entry: As any man in Illyria, whatsoever he be, under the

speaker: SIR ANDREW
text_entry: degree of my betters; and yet I will not compare

speaker: SIR ANDREW
text_entry: with an old man.

speaker: SIR TOBY BELCH
text_entry: What is thy excellence in a galliard, knight?

speaker: SIR ANDREW
text_entry: Faith, I can cut a caper.

speaker: SIR TOBY BELCH
text_entry: And I can cut the mutton to't.

speaker: SIR ANDREW
text_entry: And I think I have the back-trick simply as strong

speaker: SIR ANDREW
text_entry: as any man in Illyria.

speaker: SIR TOBY BELCH
text_entry: Wherefore are these things hid? wherefore have

speaker: SIR TOBY BELCH
text_entry: these gifts a curtain before 'em? are they like to

speaker: SIR TOBY BELCH
text_entry: take dust, like Mistress Mall's picture? why dost

speaker: SIR TOBY BELCH
text_entry: thou not go to church in a galliard and come home in

speaker: SIR TOBY BELCH
text_entry: a coranto? My very walk should be a jig; I would not

speaker: SIR TOBY BELCH
text_entry: so much as make water but in a sink-a-pace. What

speaker: SIR TOBY BELCH
text_entry: dost thou mean? Is it a world to hide virtues in?

speaker: SIR TOBY BELCH
text_entry: I did think, by the excellent constitution of thy

speaker: SIR TOBY BELCH
text_entry: leg, it was formed under the star of a galliard.

speaker: SIR ANDREW
text_entry: Ay, 'tis strong, and it does indifferent well in a

speaker: SIR ANDREW
text_entry: flame-coloured stock. Shall we set about some revels?

speaker: SIR TOBY BELCH
text_entry: What shall we do else? were we not born under Taurus?

speaker: SIR ANDREW
text_entry: Taurus! That's sides and heart.

speaker: SIR TOBY BELCH
text_entry: No, sir; it is legs and thighs. Let me see the

speaker: SIR TOBY BELCH
text_entry: caper; ha! higher: ha, ha! excellent!

speaker: SIR TOBY BELCH
text_entry: Exeunt

speaker: SIR TOBY BELCH
text_entry: SCENE IV. DUKE ORSINO's palace.

speaker: SIR TOBY BELCH
text_entry: Enter VALENTINE and VIOLA in man's attire

speaker: VALENTINE
text_entry: If the duke continue these favours towards you,

speaker: VALENTINE
text_entry: Cesario, you are like to be much advanced: he hath

speaker: VALENTINE
text_entry: known you but three days, and already you are no stranger.

speaker: VIOLA
text_entry: You either fear his humour or my negligence, that

speaker: VIOLA
text_entry: you call in question the continuance of his love:

speaker: VIOLA
text_entry: is he inconstant, sir, in his favours?

speaker: VALENTINE
text_entry: No, believe me.

speaker: VIOLA
text_entry: I thank you. Here comes the count.

speaker: VIOLA
text_entry: Enter DUKE ORSINO, CURIO, and Attendants

speaker: DUKE ORSINO
text_entry: Who saw Cesario, ho?

speaker: VIOLA
text_entry: On your attendance, my lord; here.

speaker: DUKE ORSINO
text_entry: Stand you a while aloof, Cesario,

speaker: DUKE ORSINO
text_entry: Thou know'st no less but all; I have unclasp'd

speaker: DUKE ORSINO
text_entry: To thee the book even of my secret soul:

speaker: DUKE ORSINO
text_entry: Therefore, good youth, address thy gait unto her;

speaker: DUKE ORSINO
text_entry: Be not denied access, stand at her doors,

speaker: DUKE ORSINO
text_entry: And tell them, there thy fixed foot shall grow

speaker: DUKE ORSINO
text_entry: Till thou have audience.

speaker: VIOLA
text_entry: Sure, my noble lord,

speaker: VIOLA
text_entry: If she be so abandon'd to her sorrow

speaker: VIOLA
text_entry: As it is spoke, she never will admit me.

speaker: DUKE ORSINO
text_entry: Be clamorous and leap all civil bounds

speaker: DUKE ORSINO
text_entry: Rather than make unprofited return.

speaker: VIOLA
text_entry: Say I do speak with her, my lord, what then?

speaker: DUKE ORSINO
text_entry: O, then unfold the passion of my love,

speaker: DUKE ORSINO
text_entry: Surprise her with discourse of my dear faith:

speaker: DUKE ORSINO
text_entry: It shall become thee well to act my woes;

speaker: DUKE ORSINO
text_entry: She will attend it better in thy youth

speaker: DUKE ORSINO
text_entry: Than in a nuncio's of more grave aspect.

speaker: VIOLA
text_entry: I think not so, my lord.

speaker: DUKE ORSINO
text_entry: Dear lad, believe it;

speaker: DUKE ORSINO
text_entry: For they shall yet belie thy happy years,

speaker: DUKE ORSINO
text_entry: That say thou art a man: Diana's lip

speaker: DUKE ORSINO
text_entry: Is not more smooth and rubious; thy small pipe

speaker: DUKE ORSINO
text_entry: Is as the maiden's organ, shrill and sound,

speaker: DUKE ORSINO
text_entry: And all is semblative a woman's part.

speaker: DUKE ORSINO
text_entry: I know thy constellation is right apt

speaker: DUKE ORSINO
text_entry: For this affair. Some four or five attend him;

speaker: DUKE ORSINO
text_entry: All, if you will; for I myself am best

speaker: DUKE ORSINO
text_entry: When least in company. Prosper well in this,

speaker: DUKE ORSINO
text_entry: And thou shalt live as freely as thy lord,

speaker: DUKE ORSINO
text_entry: To call his fortunes thine.

speaker: VIOLA
text_entry: I'll do my best

speaker: VIOLA
text_entry: To woo your lady:

speaker: VIOLA
text_entry: Aside

speaker: VIOLA
text_entry: yet, a barful strife!

speaker: VIOLA
text_entry: Whoe'er I woo, myself would be his wife.

speaker: VIOLA
text_entry: Exeunt

speaker: VIOLA
text_entry: SCENE V. OLIVIA'S house.

speaker: VIOLA
text_entry: Enter MARIA and Clown

speaker: MARIA
text_entry: Nay, either tell me where thou hast been, or I will

speaker: MARIA
text_entry: not open my lips so wide as a bristle may enter in

speaker: MARIA
text_entry: way of thy excuse: my lady will hang thee for thy absence.

speaker: Clown
text_entry: Let her hang me: he that is well hanged in this

speaker: Clown
text_entry: world needs to fear no colours.

speaker: MARIA
text_entry: Make that good.

speaker: Clown
text_entry: He shall see none to fear.

speaker: MARIA
text_entry: A good lenten answer: I can tell thee where that

speaker: MARIA
text_entry: saying was born, of 'I fear no colours.'

speaker: Clown
text_entry: Where, good Mistress Mary?

speaker: MARIA
text_entry: In the wars; and that may you be bold to say in your foolery.

speaker: Clown
text_entry: Well, God give them wisdom that have it; and those

speaker: Clown
text_entry: that are fools, let them use their talents.

speaker: MARIA
text_entry: Yet you will be hanged for being so long absent; or,

speaker: MARIA
text_entry: to be turned away, is not that as good as a hanging to you?

speaker: Clown
text_entry: Many a good hanging prevents a bad marriage; and,

speaker: Clown
text_entry: for turning away, let summer bear it out.

speaker: MARIA
text_entry: You are resolute, then?

speaker: Clown
text_entry: Not so, neither; but I am resolved on two points.

speaker: MARIA
text_entry: That if one break, the other will hold; or, if both

speaker: MARIA
text_entry: break, your gaskins fall.

speaker: Clown
text_entry: Apt, in good faith; very apt. Well, go thy way; if

speaker: Clown
text_entry: Sir Toby would leave drinking, thou wert as witty a

speaker: Clown
text_entry: piece of Eve's flesh as any in Illyria.

speaker: MARIA
text_entry: Peace, you rogue, no more o' that. Here comes my

speaker: MARIA
text_entry: lady: make your excuse wisely, you were best.

speaker: MARIA
text_entry: Exit

speaker: Clown
text_entry: Wit, an't be thy will, put me into good fooling!

speaker: Clown
text_entry: Those wits, that think they have thee, do very oft

speaker: Clown
text_entry: prove fools; and I, that am sure I lack thee, may

speaker: Clown
text_entry: pass for a wise man: for what says Quinapalus?

speaker: Clown
text_entry: 'Better a witty fool, than a foolish wit.'

speaker: Clown
text_entry: Enter OLIVIA with MALVOLIO

speaker: Clown
text_entry: God bless thee, lady!

speaker: OLIVIA
text_entry: Take the fool away.

speaker: Clown
text_entry: Do you not hear, fellows? Take away the lady.

speaker: OLIVIA
text_entry: Go to, you're a dry fool; I'll no more of you:

speaker: OLIVIA
text_entry: besides, you grow dishonest.

speaker: Clown
text_entry: Two faults, madonna, that drink and good counsel

speaker: Clown
text_entry: will amend: for give the dry fool drink, then is

speaker: Clown
text_entry: the fool not dry: bid the dishonest man mend

speaker: Clown
text_entry: himself; if he mend, he is no longer dishonest; if

speaker: Clown
text_entry: he cannot, let the botcher mend him. Any thing

speaker: Clown
text_entry: that's mended is but patched: virtue that

speaker: Clown
text_entry: transgresses is but patched with sin; and sin that

speaker: Clown
text_entry: amends is but patched with virtue. If that this

speaker: Clown
text_entry: simple syllogism will serve, so; if it will not,

speaker: Clown
text_entry: what remedy? As there is no true cuckold but

speaker: Clown
text_entry: calamity, so beauty's a flower. The lady bade take

speaker: Clown
text_entry: away the fool; therefore, I say again, take her away.

speaker: OLIVIA
text_entry: Sir, I bade them take away you.

speaker: Clown
text_entry: Misprision in the highest degree! Lady, cucullus non

speaker: Clown
text_entry: facit monachum; that's as much to say as I wear not

speaker: Clown
text_entry: motley in my brain. Good madonna, give me leave to

speaker: Clown
text_entry: prove you a fool.

speaker: OLIVIA
text_entry: Can you do it?

speaker: Clown
text_entry: Dexterously, good madonna.

speaker: OLIVIA
text_entry: Make your proof.

speaker: Clown
text_entry: I must catechise you for it, madonna: good my mouse

speaker: Clown
text_entry: of virtue, answer me.

speaker: OLIVIA
text_entry: Well, sir, for want of other idleness, I'll bide your proof.

speaker: Clown
text_entry: Good madonna, why mournest thou?

speaker: OLIVIA
text_entry: Good fool, for my brother's death.

speaker: Clown
text_entry: I think his soul is in hell, madonna.

speaker: OLIVIA
text_entry: I know his soul is in heaven, fool.

speaker: Clown
text_entry: The more fool, madonna, to mourn for your brother's

speaker: Clown
text_entry: soul being in heaven. Take away the fool, gentlemen.

speaker: OLIVIA
text_entry: What think you of this fool, Malvolio? doth he not mend?

speaker: MALVOLIO
text_entry: Yes, and shall do till the pangs of death shake him:

speaker: MALVOLIO
text_entry: infirmity, that decays the wise, doth ever make the

speaker: MALVOLIO
text_entry: better fool.

speaker: Clown
text_entry: God send you, sir, a speedy infirmity, for the

speaker: Clown
text_entry: better increasing your folly! Sir Toby will be

speaker: Clown
text_entry: sworn that I am no fox; but he will not pass his

speaker: Clown
text_entry: word for two pence that you are no fool.

speaker: OLIVIA
text_entry: How say you to that, Malvolio?

speaker: MALVOLIO
text_entry: I marvel your ladyship takes delight in such a

speaker: MALVOLIO
text_entry: barren rascal: I saw him put down the other day

speaker: MALVOLIO
text_entry: with an ordinary fool that has no more brain

speaker: MALVOLIO
text_entry: than a stone. Look you now, he's out of his guard

speaker: MALVOLIO
text_entry: already; unless you laugh and minister occasion to

speaker: MALVOLIO
text_entry: him, he is gagged. I protest, I take these wise men,

speaker: MALVOLIO
text_entry: that crow so at these set kind of fools, no better

speaker: MALVOLIO
text_entry: than the fools' zanies.

speaker: OLIVIA
text_entry: Oh, you are sick of self-love, Malvolio, and taste

speaker: OLIVIA
text_entry: with a distempered appetite. To be generous,

speaker: OLIVIA
text_entry: guiltless and of free disposition, is to take those

speaker: OLIVIA
text_entry: things for bird-bolts that you deem cannon-bullets:

speaker: OLIVIA
text_entry: there is no slander in an allowed fool, though he do

speaker: OLIVIA
text_entry: nothing but rail; nor no railing in a known discreet

speaker: OLIVIA
text_entry: man, though he do nothing but reprove.

speaker: Clown
text_entry: Now Mercury endue thee with leasing, for thou

speaker: Clown
text_entry: speakest well of fools!

speaker: Clown
text_entry: Re-enter MARIA

speaker: MARIA
text_entry: Madam, there is at the gate a young gentleman much

speaker: MARIA
text_entry: desires to speak with you.

speaker: OLIVIA
text_entry: From the Count Orsino, is it?

speaker: MARIA
text_entry: I know not, madam: 'tis a fair young man, and well attended.

speaker: OLIVIA
text_entry: Who of my people hold him in delay?

speaker: MARIA
text_entry: Sir Toby, madam, your kinsman.

speaker: OLIVIA
text_entry: Fetch him off, I pray you; he speaks nothing but

speaker: OLIVIA
text_entry: madman: fie on him!

speaker: OLIVIA
text_entry: Exit MARIA

speaker: OLIVIA
text_entry: Go you, Malvolio: if it be a suit from the count, I

speaker: OLIVIA
text_entry: am sick, or not at home; what you will, to dismiss it.

speaker: OLIVIA
text_entry: Exit MALVOLIO

speaker: OLIVIA
text_entry: Now you see, sir, how your fooling grows old, and

speaker: OLIVIA
text_entry: people dislike it.

speaker: Clown
text_entry: Thou hast spoke for us, madonna, as if thy eldest

speaker: Clown
text_entry: son should be a fool; whose skull Jove cram with

speaker: Clown
text_entry: brains! for,--here he comes,--one of thy kin has a

speaker: Clown
text_entry: most weak pia mater.

speaker: Clown
text_entry: Enter SIR TOBY BELCH

speaker: OLIVIA
text_entry: By mine honour, half drunk. What is he at the gate, cousin?

speaker: SIR TOBY BELCH
text_entry: A gentleman.

speaker: OLIVIA
text_entry: A gentleman! what gentleman?

speaker: SIR TOBY BELCH
text_entry: 'Tis a gentle man here--a plague o' these

speaker: SIR TOBY BELCH
text_entry: pickle-herring! How now, sot!

speaker: Clown
text_entry: Good Sir Toby!

speaker: OLIVIA
text_entry: Cousin, cousin, how have you come so early by this lethargy?

speaker: SIR TOBY BELCH
text_entry: Lechery! I defy lechery. There's one at the gate.

speaker: OLIVIA
text_entry: Ay, marry, what is he?

speaker: SIR TOBY BELCH
text_entry: Let him be the devil, an he will, I care not: give

speaker: SIR TOBY BELCH
text_entry: me faith, say I. Well, it's all one.

speaker: SIR TOBY BELCH
text_entry: Exit

speaker: OLIVIA
text_entry: What's a drunken man like, fool?

speaker: Clown
text_entry: Like a drowned man, a fool and a mad man: one

speaker: Clown
text_entry: draught above heat makes him a fool; the second mads

speaker: Clown
text_entry: him; and a third drowns him.

speaker: OLIVIA
text_entry: Go thou and seek the crowner, and let him sit o' my

speaker: OLIVIA
text_entry: coz; for he's in the third degree of drink, he's

speaker: OLIVIA
text_entry: drowned: go, look after him.

speaker: Clown
text_entry: He is but mad yet, madonna; and the fool shall look

speaker: Clown
text_entry: to the madman.

speaker: Clown
text_entry: Exit

speaker: Clown
text_entry: Re-enter MALVOLIO

speaker: MALVOLIO
text_entry: Madam, yond young fellow swears he will speak with

speaker: MALVOLIO
text_entry: you. I told him you were sick; he takes on him to

speaker: MALVOLIO
text_entry: understand so much, and therefore comes to speak

speaker: MALVOLIO
text_entry: with you. I told him you were asleep; he seems to

speaker: MALVOLIO
text_entry: have a foreknowledge of that too, and therefore

speaker: MALVOLIO
text_entry: comes to speak with you. What is to be said to him,

speaker: MALVOLIO
text_entry: lady? he's fortified against any denial.

speaker: OLIVIA
text_entry: Tell him he shall not speak with me.

speaker: MALVOLIO
text_entry: Has been told so; and he says, he'll stand at your

speaker: MALVOLIO
text_entry: door like a sheriff's post, and be the supporter to

speaker: MALVOLIO
text_entry: a bench, but he'll speak with you.

speaker: OLIVIA
text_entry: What kind o' man is he?

speaker: MALVOLIO
text_entry: Why, of mankind.

speaker: OLIVIA
text_entry: What manner of man?

speaker: MALVOLIO
text_entry: Of very ill manner; he'll speak with you, will you or no.

speaker: OLIVIA
text_entry: Of what personage and years is he?

speaker: MALVOLIO
text_entry: Not yet old enough for a man, nor young enough for

speaker: MALVOLIO
text_entry: a boy; as a squash is before 'tis a peascod, or a

speaker: MALVOLIO
text_entry: cooling when 'tis almost an apple: 'tis with him

speaker: MALVOLIO
text_entry: in standing water, between boy and man. He is very

speaker: MALVOLIO
text_entry: well-favoured and he speaks very shrewishly; one

speaker: MALVOLIO
text_entry: would think his mother's milk were scarce out of him.

speaker: OLIVIA
text_entry: Let him approach: call in my gentlewoman.

speaker: MALVOLIO
text_entry: Gentlewoman, my lady calls.

speaker: MALVOLIO
text_entry: Exit

speaker: MALVOLIO
text_entry: Re-enter MARIA

speaker: OLIVIA
text_entry: Give me my veil: come, throw it o'er my face.

speaker: OLIVIA
text_entry: We'll once more hear Orsino's embassy.

speaker: OLIVIA
text_entry: Enter VIOLA, and Attendants

speaker: VIOLA
text_entry: The honourable lady of the house, which is she?

speaker: OLIVIA
text_entry: Speak to me; I shall answer for her.

speaker: OLIVIA
text_entry: Your will?

speaker: VIOLA
text_entry: Most radiant, exquisite and unmatchable beauty,--I

speaker: VIOLA
text_entry: pray you, tell me if this be the lady of the house,

speaker: VIOLA
text_entry: for I never saw her: I would be loath to cast away

speaker: VIOLA
text_entry: my speech, for besides that it is excellently well

speaker: VIOLA
text_entry: penned, I have taken great pains to con it. Good

speaker: VIOLA
text_entry: beauties, let me sustain no scorn; I am very

speaker: VIOLA
text_entry: comptible, even to the least sinister usage.

speaker: OLIVIA
text_entry: Whence came you, sir?

speaker: VIOLA
text_entry: I can say little more than I have studied, and that

speaker: VIOLA
text_entry: question's out of my part. Good gentle one, give me

speaker: VIOLA
text_entry: modest assurance if you be the lady of the house,

speaker: VIOLA
text_entry: that I may proceed in my speech.

speaker: OLIVIA
text_entry: Are you a comedian?

speaker: VIOLA
text_entry: No, my profound heart: and yet, by the very fangs

speaker: VIOLA
text_entry: of malice I swear, I am not that I play. Are you

speaker: VIOLA
text_entry: the lady of the house?

speaker: OLIVIA
text_entry: If I do not usurp myself, I am.

speaker: VIOLA
text_entry: Most certain, if you are she, you do usurp

speaker: VIOLA
text_entry: yourself; for what is yours to bestow is not yours

speaker: VIOLA
text_entry: to reserve. But this is from my commission: I will

speaker: VIOLA
text_entry: on with my speech in your praise, and then show you

speaker: VIOLA
text_entry: the heart of my message.

speaker: OLIVIA
text_entry: Come to what is important in't: I forgive you the praise.

speaker: VIOLA
text_entry: Alas, I took great pains to study it, and 'tis poetical.

speaker: OLIVIA
text_entry: It is the more like to be feigned: I pray you,

speaker: OLIVIA
text_entry: keep it in. I heard you were saucy at my gates,

speaker: OLIVIA
text_entry: and allowed your approach rather to wonder at you

speaker: OLIVIA
text_entry: than to hear you. If you be not mad, be gone; if

speaker: OLIVIA
text_entry: you have reason, be brief: 'tis not that time of

speaker: OLIVIA
text_entry: moon with me to make one in so skipping a dialogue.

speaker: MARIA
text_entry: Will you hoist sail, sir? here lies your way.

speaker: VIOLA
text_entry: No, good swabber; I am to hull here a little

speaker: VIOLA
text_entry: longer. Some mollification for your giant, sweet

speaker: VIOLA
text_entry: lady. Tell me your mind: I am a messenger.

speaker: OLIVIA
text_entry: Sure, you have some hideous matter to deliver, when

speaker: OLIVIA
text_entry: the courtesy of it is so fearful. Speak your office.

speaker: VIOLA
text_entry: It alone concerns your ear. I bring no overture of

speaker: VIOLA
text_entry: war, no taxation of homage: I hold the olive in my

speaker: VIOLA
text_entry: hand; my words are as fun of peace as matter.

speaker: OLIVIA
text_entry: Yet you began rudely. What are you? what would you?

speaker: VIOLA
text_entry: The rudeness that hath appeared in me have I

speaker: VIOLA
text_entry: learned from my entertainment. What I am, and what I

speaker: VIOLA
text_entry: would, are as secret as maidenhead; to your ears,

speaker: VIOLA
text_entry: divinity, to any other's, profanation.

speaker: OLIVIA
text_entry: Give us the place alone: we will hear this divinity.

speaker: OLIVIA
text_entry: Exeunt MARIA and Attendants

speaker: OLIVIA
text_entry: Now, sir, what is your text?

speaker: VIOLA
text_entry: Most sweet lady,--

speaker: OLIVIA
text_entry: A comfortable doctrine, and much may be said of it.

speaker: OLIVIA
text_entry: Where lies your text?

speaker: VIOLA
text_entry: In Orsino's bosom.

speaker: OLIVIA
text_entry: In his bosom! In what chapter of his bosom?

speaker: VIOLA
text_entry: To answer by the method, in the first of his heart.

speaker: OLIVIA
text_entry: O, I have read it: it is heresy. Have you no more to say?

speaker: VIOLA
text_entry: Good madam, let me see your face.

speaker: OLIVIA
text_entry: Have you any commission from your lord to negotiate

speaker: OLIVIA
text_entry: with my face? You are now out of your text: but

speaker: OLIVIA
text_entry: we will draw the curtain and show you the picture.

speaker: OLIVIA
text_entry: Look you, sir, such a one I was this present: is't

speaker: OLIVIA
text_entry: not well done?

speaker: OLIVIA
text_entry: Unveiling

speaker: VIOLA
text_entry: Excellently done, if God did all.

speaker: OLIVIA
text_entry: 'Tis in grain, sir; 'twill endure wind and weather.

speaker: VIOLA
text_entry: 'Tis beauty truly blent, whose red and white

speaker: VIOLA
text_entry: Nature's own sweet and cunning hand laid on:

speaker: VIOLA
text_entry: Lady, you are the cruell'st she alive,

speaker: VIOLA
text_entry: If you will lead these graces to the grave

speaker: VIOLA
text_entry: And leave the world no copy.

speaker: OLIVIA
text_entry: O, sir, I will not be so hard-hearted; I will give

speaker: OLIVIA
text_entry: out divers schedules of my beauty: it shall be

speaker: OLIVIA
text_entry: inventoried, and every particle and utensil

speaker: OLIVIA
text_entry: labelled to my will: as, item, two lips,

speaker: OLIVIA
text_entry: indifferent red; item, two grey eyes, with lids to

speaker: OLIVIA
text_entry: them; item, one neck, one chin, and so forth. Were

speaker: OLIVIA
text_entry: you sent hither to praise me?

speaker: VIOLA
text_entry: I see you what you are, you are too proud;

speaker: VIOLA
text_entry: But, if you were the devil, you are fair.

speaker: VIOLA
text_entry: My lord and master loves you: O, such love

speaker: VIOLA
text_entry: Could be but recompensed, though you were crown'd

speaker: VIOLA
text_entry: The nonpareil of beauty!

speaker: OLIVIA
text_entry: How does he love me?

speaker: VIOLA
text_entry: With adorations, fertile tears,

speaker: VIOLA
text_entry: With groans that thunder love, with sighs of fire.

speaker: OLIVIA
text_entry: Your lord does know my mind; I cannot love him:

speaker: OLIVIA
text_entry: Yet I suppose him virtuous, know him noble,

speaker: OLIVIA
text_entry: Of great estate, of fresh and stainless youth;

speaker: OLIVIA
text_entry: In voices well divulged, free, learn'd and valiant;

speaker: OLIVIA
text_entry: And in dimension and the shape of nature

speaker: OLIVIA
text_entry: A gracious person: but yet I cannot love him;

speaker: OLIVIA
text_entry: He might have took his answer long ago.

speaker: VIOLA
text_entry: If I did love you in my master's flame,

speaker: VIOLA
text_entry: With such a suffering, such a deadly life,

speaker: VIOLA
text_entry: In your denial I would find no sense;

speaker: VIOLA
text_entry: I would not understand it.

speaker: OLIVIA
text_entry: Why, what would you?

speaker: VIOLA
text_entry: Make me a willow cabin at your gate,

speaker: VIOLA
text_entry: And call upon my soul within the house;

speaker: VIOLA
text_entry: Write loyal cantons of contemned love

speaker: VIOLA
text_entry: And sing them loud even in the dead of night;

speaker: VIOLA
text_entry: Halloo your name to the reverberate hills

speaker: VIOLA
text_entry: And make the babbling gossip of the air

speaker: VIOLA
text_entry: Cry out 'Olivia!' O, You should not rest

speaker: VIOLA
text_entry: Between the elements of air and earth,

speaker: VIOLA
text_entry: But you should pity me!

speaker: OLIVIA
text_entry: You might do much.

speaker: OLIVIA
text_entry: What is your parentage?

speaker: VIOLA
text_entry: Above my fortunes, yet my state is well:

speaker: VIOLA
text_entry: I am a gentleman.

speaker: OLIVIA
text_entry: Get you to your lord;

speaker: OLIVIA
text_entry: I cannot love him: let him send no more;

speaker: OLIVIA
text_entry: Unless, perchance, you come to me again,

speaker: OLIVIA
text_entry: To tell me how he takes it. Fare you well:

speaker: OLIVIA
text_entry: I thank you for your pains: spend this for me.

speaker: VIOLA
text_entry: I am no fee'd post, lady; keep your purse:

speaker: VIOLA
text_entry: My master, not myself, lacks recompense.

speaker: VIOLA
text_entry: Love make his heart of flint that you shall love;

speaker: VIOLA
text_entry: And let your fervor, like my master's, be

speaker: VIOLA
text_entry: Placed in contempt! Farewell, fair cruelty.

speaker: VIOLA
text_entry: Exit

speaker: OLIVIA
text_entry: 'What is your parentage?'

speaker: OLIVIA
text_entry: 'Above my fortunes, yet my state is well:

speaker: OLIVIA
text_entry: I am a gentleman.' I'll be sworn thou art;

speaker: OLIVIA
text_entry: Thy tongue, thy face, thy limbs, actions and spirit,

speaker: OLIVIA
text_entry: Do give thee five-fold blazon: not too fast:

speaker: OLIVIA
text_entry: soft, soft!

speaker: OLIVIA
text_entry: Unless the master were the man. How now!

speaker: OLIVIA
text_entry: Even so quickly may one catch the plague?

speaker: OLIVIA
text_entry: Methinks I feel this youth's perfections

speaker: OLIVIA
text_entry: With an invisible and subtle stealth

speaker: OLIVIA
text_entry: To creep in at mine eyes. Well, let it be.

speaker: OLIVIA
text_entry: What ho, Malvolio!

speaker: OLIVIA
text_entry: Re-enter MALVOLIO

speaker: MALVOLIO
text_entry: Here, madam, at your service.

speaker: OLIVIA
text_entry: Run after that same peevish messenger,

speaker: OLIVIA
text_entry: The county's man: he left this ring behind him,

speaker: OLIVIA
text_entry: Would I or not: tell him I'll none of it.

speaker: OLIVIA
text_entry: Desire him not to flatter with his lord,

speaker: OLIVIA
text_entry: Nor hold him up with hopes; I am not for him:

speaker: OLIVIA
text_entry: If that the youth will come this way to-morrow,

speaker: OLIVIA
text_entry: I'll give him reasons for't: hie thee, Malvolio.

speaker: MALVOLIO
text_entry: Madam, I will.

speaker: MALVOLIO
text_entry: Exit

speaker: OLIVIA
text_entry: I do I know not what, and fear to find

speaker: OLIVIA
text_entry: Mine eye too great a flatterer for my mind.

speaker: OLIVIA
text_entry: Fate, show thy force: ourselves we do not owe;

speaker: OLIVIA
text_entry: What is decreed must be, and be this so.

speaker: OLIVIA
text_entry: Exit

speaker: OLIVIA
text_entry: ACT II

speaker: OLIVIA
text_entry: SCENE I. The sea-coast.

speaker: OLIVIA
text_entry: Enter ANTONIO and SEBASTIAN

speaker: ANTONIO
text_entry: Will you stay no longer? nor will you not that I go with you?

speaker: SEBASTIAN
text_entry: By your patience, no. My stars shine darkly over

speaker: SEBASTIAN
text_entry: me: the malignancy of my fate might perhaps

speaker: SEBASTIAN
text_entry: distemper yours; therefore I shall crave of you your

speaker: SEBASTIAN
text_entry: leave that I may bear my evils alone: it were a bad

speaker: SEBASTIAN
text_entry: recompense for your love, to lay any of them on you.

speaker: SEBASTIAN
text_entry: ANTONIO: Let me yet know of you whither you are bound.

speaker: SEBASTIAN
text_entry: No, sooth, sir: my determinate voyage is mere

speaker: SEBASTIAN
text_entry: extravagancy. But I perceive in you so excellent a

speaker: SEBASTIAN
text_entry: touch of modesty, that you will not extort from me

speaker: SEBASTIAN
text_entry: what I am willing to keep in; therefore it charges

speaker: SEBASTIAN
text_entry: me in manners the rather to express myself. You

speaker: SEBASTIAN
text_entry: must know of me then, Antonio, my name is Sebastian,

speaker: SEBASTIAN
text_entry: which I called Roderigo. My father was that

speaker: SEBASTIAN
text_entry: Sebastian of Messaline, whom I know you have heard

speaker: SEBASTIAN
text_entry: of. He left behind him myself and a sister, both

speaker: SEBASTIAN
text_entry: born in an hour: if the heavens had been pleased,

speaker: SEBASTIAN
text_entry: would we had so ended! but you, sir, altered that;

speaker: SEBASTIAN
text_entry: for some hour before you took me from the breach of

speaker: SEBASTIAN
text_entry: the sea was my sister drowned.

speaker: ANTONIO
text_entry: Alas the day!

speaker: SEBASTIAN
text_entry: A lady, sir, though it was said she much resembled

speaker: SEBASTIAN
text_entry: me, was yet of many accounted beautiful: but,

speaker: SEBASTIAN
text_entry: though I could not with such estimable wonder

speaker: SEBASTIAN
text_entry: overfar believe that, yet thus far I will boldly

speaker: SEBASTIAN
text_entry: publish her; she bore a mind that envy could not but

speaker: SEBASTIAN
text_entry: call fair. She is drowned already, sir, with salt

speaker: SEBASTIAN
text_entry: water, though I seem to drown her remembrance again with more.

speaker: ANTONIO
text_entry: Pardon me, sir, your bad entertainment.

speaker: SEBASTIAN
text_entry: O good Antonio, forgive me your trouble.

speaker: ANTONIO
text_entry: If you will not murder me for my love, let me be

speaker: ANTONIO
text_entry: your servant.

speaker: SEBASTIAN
text_entry: If you will not undo what you have done, that is,

speaker: SEBASTIAN
text_entry: kill him whom you have recovered, desire it not.

speaker: SEBASTIAN
text_entry: Fare ye well at once: my bosom is full of kindness,

speaker: SEBASTIAN
text_entry: and I am yet so near the manners of my mother, that

speaker: SEBASTIAN
text_entry: upon the least occasion more mine eyes will tell

speaker: SEBASTIAN
text_entry: tales of me. I am bound to the Count Orsino's court: farewell.

speaker: SEBASTIAN
text_entry: Exit

speaker: ANTONIO
text_entry: The gentleness of all the gods go with thee!

speaker: ANTONIO
text_entry: I have many enemies in Orsino's court,

speaker: ANTONIO
text_entry: Else would I very shortly see thee there.

speaker: ANTONIO
text_entry: But, come what may, I do adore thee so,

speaker: ANTONIO
text_entry: That danger shall seem sport, and I will go.

speaker: ANTONIO
text_entry: Exit

speaker: ANTONIO
text_entry: SCENE II. A street.

speaker: ANTONIO
text_entry: Enter VIOLA, MALVOLIO following

speaker: MALVOLIO
text_entry: Were not you even now with the Countess Olivia?

speaker: VIOLA
text_entry: Even now, sir; on a moderate pace I have since

speaker: VIOLA
text_entry: arrived but hither.

speaker: MALVOLIO
text_entry: She returns this ring to you, sir: you might have

speaker: MALVOLIO
text_entry: saved me my pains, to have taken it away yourself.

speaker: MALVOLIO
text_entry: She adds, moreover, that you should put your lord

speaker: MALVOLIO
text_entry: into a desperate assurance she will none of him:

speaker: MALVOLIO
text_entry: and one thing more, that you be never so hardy to

speaker: MALVOLIO
text_entry: come again in his affairs, unless it be to report

speaker: MALVOLIO
text_entry: your lord's taking of this. Receive it so.

speaker: VIOLA
text_entry: She took the ring of me: I'll none of it.

speaker: MALVOLIO
text_entry: Come, sir, you peevishly threw it to her; and her

speaker: MALVOLIO
text_entry: will is, it should be so returned: if it be worth

speaker: MALVOLIO
text_entry: stooping for, there it lies in your eye; if not, be

speaker: MALVOLIO
text_entry: it his that finds it.

speaker: MALVOLIO
text_entry: Exit

speaker: VIOLA
text_entry: I left no ring with her: what means this lady?

speaker: VIOLA
text_entry: Fortune forbid my outside have not charm'd her!

speaker: VIOLA
text_entry: She made good view of me; indeed, so much,

speaker: VIOLA
text_entry: That sure methought her eyes had lost her tongue,

speaker: VIOLA
text_entry: For she did speak in starts distractedly.

speaker: VIOLA
text_entry: She loves me, sure; the cunning of her passion

speaker: VIOLA
text_entry: Invites me in this churlish messenger.

speaker: VIOLA
text_entry: None of my lord's ring! why, he sent her none.

speaker: VIOLA
text_entry: I am the man: if it be so, as 'tis,

speaker: VIOLA
text_entry: Poor lady, she were better love a dream.

speaker: VIOLA
text_entry: Disguise, I see, thou art a wickedness,

speaker: VIOLA
text_entry: Wherein the pregnant enemy does much.

speaker: VIOLA
text_entry: How easy is it for the proper-false

speaker: VIOLA
text_entry: In women's waxen hearts to set their forms!

speaker: VIOLA
text_entry: Alas, our frailty is the cause, not we!

speaker: VIOLA
text_entry: For such as we are made of, such we be.

speaker: VIOLA
text_entry: How will this fadge? my master loves her dearly;

speaker: VIOLA
text_entry: And I, poor monster, fond as much on him;

speaker: VIOLA
text_entry: And she, mistaken, seems to dote on me.

speaker: VIOLA
text_entry: What will become of this? As I am man,

speaker: VIOLA
text_entry: My state is desperate for my master's love;

speaker: VIOLA
text_entry: As I am woman,--now alas the day!--

speaker: VIOLA
text_entry: What thriftless sighs shall poor Olivia breathe!

speaker: VIOLA
text_entry: O time! thou must untangle this, not I;

speaker: VIOLA
text_entry: It is too hard a knot for me to untie!

speaker: VIOLA
text_entry: Exit

speaker: VIOLA
text_entry: SCENE III. OLIVIA's house.

speaker: VIOLA
text_entry: Enter SIR TOBY BELCH and SIR ANDREW

speaker: SIR TOBY BELCH
text_entry: Approach, Sir Andrew: not to be abed after

speaker: SIR TOBY BELCH
text_entry: midnight is to be up betimes; and 'diluculo

speaker: SIR TOBY BELCH
text_entry: surgere,' thou know'st,--

speaker: SIR ANDREW
text_entry: Nay, my troth, I know not: but I know, to be up

speaker: SIR ANDREW
text_entry: late is to be up late.

speaker: SIR TOBY BELCH
text_entry: A false conclusion: I hate it as an unfilled can.

speaker: SIR TOBY BELCH
text_entry: To be up after midnight and to go to bed then, is

speaker: SIR TOBY BELCH
text_entry: early: so that to go to bed after midnight is to go

speaker: SIR TOBY BELCH
text_entry: to bed betimes. Does not our life consist of the

speaker: SIR TOBY BELCH
text_entry: four elements?

speaker: SIR ANDREW
text_entry: Faith, so they say; but I think it rather consists

speaker: SIR ANDREW
text_entry: of eating and drinking.

speaker: SIR TOBY BELCH
text_entry: Thou'rt a scholar; let us therefore eat and drink.

speaker: SIR TOBY BELCH
text_entry: Marian, I say! a stoup of wine!

speaker: SIR TOBY BELCH
text_entry: Enter Clown

speaker: SIR ANDREW
text_entry: Here comes the fool, i' faith.

speaker: Clown
text_entry: How now, my hearts! did you never see the picture

speaker: Clown
text_entry: of 'we three'?

speaker: SIR TOBY BELCH
text_entry: Welcome, ass. Now let's have a catch.

speaker: SIR ANDREW
text_entry: By my troth, the fool has an excellent breast. I

speaker: SIR ANDREW
text_entry: had rather than forty shillings I had such a leg,

speaker: SIR ANDREW
text_entry: and so sweet a breath to sing, as the fool has. In

speaker: SIR ANDREW
text_entry: sooth, thou wast in very gracious fooling last

speaker: SIR ANDREW
text_entry: night, when thou spokest of Pigrogromitus, of the

speaker: SIR ANDREW
text_entry: Vapians passing the equinoctial of Queubus: 'twas

speaker: SIR ANDREW
text_entry: very good, i' faith. I sent thee sixpence for thy

speaker: SIR ANDREW
text_entry: leman: hadst it?

speaker: Clown
text_entry: I did impeticos thy gratillity; for Malvolio's nose

speaker: Clown
text_entry: is no whipstock: my lady has a white hand, and the

speaker: Clown
text_entry: Myrmidons are no bottle-ale houses.

speaker: SIR ANDREW
text_entry: Excellent! why, this is the best fooling, when all

speaker: SIR ANDREW
text_entry: is done. Now, a song.

speaker: SIR TOBY BELCH
text_entry: Come on; there is sixpence for you: let's have a song.

speaker: SIR ANDREW
text_entry: There's a testril of me too: if one knight give a--

speaker: Clown
text_entry: Would you have a love-song, or a song of good life?

speaker: SIR TOBY BELCH
text_entry: A love-song, a love-song.

speaker: SIR ANDREW
text_entry: Ay, ay: I care not for good life.

speaker: Clown
text_entry: [Sings]

speaker: Clown
text_entry: O mistress mine, where are you roaming?

speaker: Clown
text_entry: O, stay and hear; your true love's coming,

speaker: Clown
text_entry: That can sing both high and low:

speaker: Clown
text_entry: Trip no further, pretty sweeting;

speaker: Clown
text_entry: Journeys end in lovers meeting,

speaker: Clown
text_entry: Every wise man's son doth know.

speaker: SIR ANDREW
text_entry: Excellent good, i' faith.

speaker: SIR TOBY BELCH
text_entry: Good, good.

speaker: Clown
text_entry: [Sings]

speaker: Clown
text_entry: What is love? 'tis not hereafter;

speaker: Clown
text_entry: Present mirth hath present laughter;

speaker: Clown
text_entry: What's to come is still unsure:

speaker: Clown
text_entry: In delay there lies no plenty;

speaker: Clown
text_entry: Then come kiss me, sweet and twenty,

speaker: Clown
text_entry: Youth's a stuff will not endure.

speaker: SIR ANDREW
text_entry: A mellifluous voice, as I am true knight.

speaker: SIR TOBY BELCH
text_entry: A contagious breath.

speaker: SIR ANDREW
text_entry: Very sweet and contagious, i' faith.

speaker: SIR TOBY BELCH
text_entry: To hear by the nose, it is dulcet in contagion.

speaker: SIR TOBY BELCH
text_entry: But shall we make the welkin dance indeed? shall we

speaker: SIR TOBY BELCH
text_entry: rouse the night-owl in a catch that will draw three

speaker: SIR TOBY BELCH
text_entry: souls out of one weaver? shall we do that?

speaker: SIR ANDREW
text_entry: An you love me, let's do't: I am dog at a catch.

speaker: Clown
text_entry: By'r lady, sir, and some dogs will catch well.

speaker: SIR ANDREW
text_entry: Most certain. Let our catch be, 'Thou knave.'

speaker: Clown
text_entry: 'Hold thy peace, thou knave,' knight? I shall be

speaker: Clown
text_entry: constrained in't to call thee knave, knight.

speaker: SIR ANDREW
text_entry: 'Tis not the first time I have constrained one to

speaker: SIR ANDREW
text_entry: call me knave. Begin, fool: it begins 'Hold thy peace.'

speaker: Clown
text_entry: I shall never begin if I hold my peace.

speaker: SIR ANDREW
text_entry: Good, i' faith. Come, begin.

speaker: SIR ANDREW
text_entry: Catch sung

speaker: SIR ANDREW
text_entry: Enter MARIA

speaker: MARIA
text_entry: What a caterwauling do you keep here! If my lady

speaker: MARIA
text_entry: have not called up her steward Malvolio and bid him

speaker: MARIA
text_entry: turn you out of doors, never trust me.

speaker: SIR TOBY BELCH
text_entry: My lady's a Cataian, we are politicians, Malvolio's

speaker: SIR TOBY BELCH
text_entry: a Peg-a-Ramsey, and 'Three merry men be we.' Am not

speaker: SIR TOBY BELCH
text_entry: I consanguineous? am I not of her blood?

speaker: SIR TOBY BELCH
text_entry: Tillyvally. Lady!

speaker: SIR TOBY BELCH
text_entry: Sings

speaker: SIR TOBY BELCH
text_entry: 'There dwelt a man in Babylon, lady, lady!'

speaker: Clown
text_entry: Beshrew me, the knight's in admirable fooling.

speaker: SIR ANDREW
text_entry: Ay, he does well enough if he be disposed, and so do

speaker: SIR ANDREW
text_entry: I too: he does it with a better grace, but I do it

speaker: SIR ANDREW
text_entry: more natural.

speaker: SIR TOBY BELCH
text_entry: [Sings]  'O, the twelfth day of December,'--

speaker: MARIA
text_entry: For the love o' God, peace!

speaker: MARIA
text_entry: Enter MALVOLIO

speaker: MALVOLIO
text_entry: My masters, are you mad? or what are you? Have ye

speaker: MALVOLIO
text_entry: no wit, manners, nor honesty, but to gabble like

speaker: MALVOLIO
text_entry: tinkers at this time of night? Do ye make an

speaker: MALVOLIO
text_entry: alehouse of my lady's house, that ye squeak out your

speaker: MALVOLIO
text_entry: coziers' catches without any mitigation or remorse

speaker: MALVOLIO
text_entry: of voice? Is there no respect of place, persons, nor

speaker: MALVOLIO
text_entry: time in you?

speaker: SIR TOBY BELCH
text_entry: We did keep time, sir, in our catches. Sneck up!

speaker: MALVOLIO
text_entry: Sir Toby, I must be round with you. My lady bade me

speaker: MALVOLIO
text_entry: tell you, that, though she harbours you as her

speaker: MALVOLIO
text_entry: kinsman, she's nothing allied to your disorders. If

speaker: MALVOLIO
text_entry: you can separate yourself and your misdemeanors, you

speaker: MALVOLIO
text_entry: are welcome to the house; if not, an it would please

speaker: MALVOLIO
text_entry: you to take leave of her, she is very willing to bid

speaker: MALVOLIO
text_entry: you farewell.

speaker: SIR TOBY BELCH
text_entry: 'Farewell, dear heart, since I must needs be gone.'

speaker: MARIA
text_entry: Nay, good Sir Toby.

speaker: Clown
text_entry: 'His eyes do show his days are almost done.'

speaker: MALVOLIO
text_entry: Is't even so?

speaker: SIR TOBY BELCH
text_entry: 'But I will never die.'

speaker: Clown
text_entry: Sir Toby, there you lie.

speaker: MALVOLIO
text_entry: This is much credit to you.

speaker: SIR TOBY BELCH
text_entry: 'Shall I bid him go?'

speaker: Clown
text_entry: 'What an if you do?'

speaker: SIR TOBY BELCH
text_entry: 'Shall I bid him go, and spare not?'

speaker: Clown
text_entry: 'O no, no, no, no, you dare not.'

speaker: SIR TOBY BELCH
text_entry: Out o' tune, sir: ye lie. Art any more than a

speaker: SIR TOBY BELCH
text_entry: steward? Dost thou think, because thou art

speaker: SIR TOBY BELCH
text_entry: virtuous, there shall be no more cakes and ale?

speaker: Clown
text_entry: Yes, by Saint Anne, and ginger shall be hot i' the

speaker: Clown
text_entry: mouth too.

speaker: SIR TOBY BELCH
text_entry: Thou'rt i' the right. Go, sir, rub your chain with

speaker: SIR TOBY BELCH
text_entry: crumbs. A stoup of wine, Maria!

speaker: MALVOLIO
text_entry: Mistress Mary, if you prized my lady's favour at any

speaker: MALVOLIO
text_entry: thing more than contempt, you would not give means

speaker: MALVOLIO
text_entry: for this uncivil rule: she shall know of it, by this hand.

speaker: MALVOLIO
text_entry: Exit

speaker: MARIA
text_entry: Go shake your ears.

speaker: SIR ANDREW
text_entry: 'Twere as good a deed as to drink when a man's

speaker: SIR ANDREW
text_entry: a-hungry, to challenge him the field, and then to

speaker: SIR ANDREW
text_entry: break promise with him and make a fool of him.

speaker: SIR TOBY BELCH
text_entry: Do't, knight: I'll write thee a challenge: or I'll

speaker: SIR TOBY BELCH
text_entry: deliver thy indignation to him by word of mouth.

speaker: MARIA
text_entry: Sweet Sir Toby, be patient for tonight: since the

speaker: MARIA
text_entry: youth of the count's was today with thy lady, she is

speaker: MARIA
text_entry: much out of quiet. For Monsieur Malvolio, let me

speaker: MARIA
text_entry: alone with him: if I do not gull him into a

speaker: MARIA
text_entry: nayword, and make him a common recreation, do not

speaker: MARIA
text_entry: think I have wit enough to lie straight in my bed:

speaker: MARIA
text_entry: I know I can do it.

speaker: SIR TOBY BELCH
text_entry: Possess us, possess us; tell us something of him.

speaker: MARIA
text_entry: Marry, sir, sometimes he is a kind of puritan.

speaker: SIR ANDREW
text_entry: O, if I thought that I'ld beat him like a dog!

speaker: SIR TOBY BELCH
text_entry: What, for being a puritan? thy exquisite reason,

speaker: SIR TOBY BELCH
text_entry: dear knight?

speaker: SIR ANDREW
text_entry: I have no exquisite reason for't, but I have reason

speaker: SIR ANDREW
text_entry: good enough.

speaker: MARIA
text_entry: The devil a puritan that he is, or any thing

speaker: MARIA
text_entry: constantly, but a time-pleaser; an affectioned ass,

speaker: MARIA
text_entry: that cons state without book and utters it by great

speaker: MARIA
text_entry: swarths: the best persuaded of himself, so

speaker: MARIA
text_entry: crammed, as he thinks, with excellencies, that it is

speaker: MARIA
text_entry: his grounds of faith that all that look on him love

speaker: MARIA
text_entry: him; and on that vice in him will my revenge find

speaker: MARIA
text_entry: notable cause to work.

speaker: SIR TOBY BELCH
text_entry: What wilt thou do?

speaker: MARIA
text_entry: I will drop in his way some obscure epistles of

speaker: MARIA
text_entry: love; wherein, by the colour of his beard, the shape

speaker: MARIA
text_entry: of his leg, the manner of his gait, the expressure

speaker: MARIA
text_entry: of his eye, forehead, and complexion, he shall find

speaker: MARIA
text_entry: himself most feelingly personated. I can write very

speaker: MARIA
text_entry: like my lady your niece: on a forgotten matter we

speaker: MARIA
text_entry: can hardly make distinction of our hands.

speaker: SIR TOBY BELCH
text_entry: Excellent! I smell a device.

speaker: SIR ANDREW
text_entry: I have't in my nose too.

speaker: SIR TOBY BELCH
text_entry: He shall think, by the letters that thou wilt drop,

speaker: SIR TOBY BELCH
text_entry: that they come from my niece, and that she's in

speaker: SIR TOBY BELCH
text_entry: love with him.

speaker: MARIA
text_entry: My purpose is, indeed, a horse of that colour.

speaker: SIR ANDREW
text_entry: And your horse now would make him an ass.

speaker: MARIA
text_entry: Ass, I doubt not.

speaker: SIR ANDREW
text_entry: O, 'twill be admirable!

speaker: MARIA
text_entry: Sport royal, I warrant you: I know my physic will

speaker: MARIA
text_entry: work with him. I will plant you two, and let the

speaker: MARIA
text_entry: fool make a third, where he shall find the letter:

speaker: MARIA
text_entry: observe his construction of it. For this night, to

speaker: MARIA
text_entry: bed, and dream on the event. Farewell.

speaker: MARIA
text_entry: Exit

speaker: SIR TOBY BELCH
text_entry: Good night, Penthesilea.

speaker: SIR ANDREW
text_entry: Before me, she's a good wench.

speaker: SIR TOBY BELCH
text_entry: She's a beagle, true-bred, and one that adores me:

speaker: SIR TOBY BELCH
text_entry: what o' that?

speaker: SIR ANDREW
text_entry: I was adored once too.

speaker: SIR TOBY BELCH
text_entry: Let's to bed, knight. Thou hadst need send for

speaker: SIR TOBY BELCH
text_entry: more money.

speaker: SIR ANDREW
text_entry: If I cannot recover your niece, I am a foul way out.

speaker: SIR TOBY BELCH
text_entry: Send for money, knight: if thou hast her not i'

speaker: SIR TOBY BELCH
text_entry: the end, call me cut.

speaker: SIR ANDREW
text_entry: If I do not, never trust me, take it how you will.

speaker: SIR TOBY BELCH
text_entry: Come, come, I'll go burn some sack; 'tis too late

speaker: SIR TOBY BELCH
text_entry: to go to bed now: come, knight; come, knight.

speaker: SIR TOBY BELCH
text_entry: Exeunt

speaker: SIR TOBY BELCH
text_entry: SCENE IV. DUKE ORSINO's palace.

speaker: SIR TOBY BELCH
text_entry: Enter DUKE ORSINO, VIOLA, CURIO, and others

speaker: DUKE ORSINO
text_entry: Give me some music. Now, good morrow, friends.

speaker: DUKE ORSINO
text_entry: Now, good Cesario, but that piece of song,

speaker: DUKE ORSINO
text_entry: That old and antique song we heard last night:

speaker: DUKE ORSINO
text_entry: Methought it did relieve my passion much,

speaker: DUKE ORSINO
text_entry: More than light airs and recollected terms

speaker: DUKE ORSINO
text_entry: Of these most brisk and giddy-paced times:

speaker: DUKE ORSINO
text_entry: Come, but one verse.

speaker: CURIO
text_entry: He is not here, so please your lordship that should sing it.

speaker: DUKE ORSINO
text_entry: Who was it?

speaker: CURIO
text_entry: Feste, the jester, my lord; a fool that the lady

speaker: CURIO
text_entry: Olivia's father took much delight in. He is about the house.

speaker: DUKE ORSINO
text_entry: Seek him out, and play the tune the while.

speaker: DUKE ORSINO
text_entry: Exit CURIO. Music plays

speaker: DUKE ORSINO
text_entry: Come hither, boy: if ever thou shalt love,

speaker: DUKE ORSINO
text_entry: In the sweet pangs of it remember me;

speaker: DUKE ORSINO
text_entry: For such as I am all true lovers are,

speaker: DUKE ORSINO
text_entry: Unstaid and skittish in all motions else,

speaker: DUKE ORSINO
text_entry: Save in the constant image of the creature

speaker: DUKE ORSINO
text_entry: That is beloved. How dost thou like this tune?

speaker: VIOLA
text_entry: It gives a very echo to the seat

speaker: VIOLA
text_entry: Where Love is throned.

speaker: DUKE ORSINO
text_entry: Thou dost speak masterly:

speaker: DUKE ORSINO
text_entry: My life upon't, young though thou art, thine eye

speaker: DUKE ORSINO
text_entry: Hath stay'd upon some favour that it loves:

speaker: DUKE ORSINO
text_entry: Hath it not, boy?

speaker: VIOLA
text_entry: A little, by your favour.

speaker: DUKE ORSINO
text_entry: What kind of woman is't?

speaker: VIOLA
text_entry: Of your complexion.

speaker: DUKE ORSINO
text_entry: She is not worth thee, then. What years, i' faith?

speaker: VIOLA
text_entry: About your years, my lord.

speaker: DUKE ORSINO
text_entry: Too old by heaven: let still the woman take

speaker: DUKE ORSINO
text_entry: An elder than herself: so wears she to him,

speaker: DUKE ORSINO
text_entry: So sways she level in her husband's heart:

speaker: DUKE ORSINO
text_entry: For, boy, however we do praise ourselves,

speaker: DUKE ORSINO
text_entry: Our fancies are more giddy and unfirm,

speaker: DUKE ORSINO
text_entry: More longing, wavering, sooner lost and worn,

speaker: DUKE ORSINO
text_entry: Than women's are.

speaker: VIOLA
text_entry: I think it well, my lord.

speaker: DUKE ORSINO
text_entry: Then let thy love be younger than thyself,

speaker: DUKE ORSINO
text_entry: Or thy affection cannot hold the bent;

speaker: DUKE ORSINO
text_entry: For women are as roses, whose fair flower

speaker: DUKE ORSINO
text_entry: Being once display'd, doth fall that very hour.

speaker: VIOLA
text_entry: And so they are: alas, that they are so;

speaker: VIOLA
text_entry: To die, even when they to perfection grow!

speaker: VIOLA
text_entry: Re-enter CURIO and Clown

speaker: DUKE ORSINO
text_entry: O, fellow, come, the song we had last night.

speaker: DUKE ORSINO
text_entry: Mark it, Cesario, it is old and plain;

speaker: DUKE ORSINO
text_entry: The spinsters and the knitters in the sun

speaker: DUKE ORSINO
text_entry: And the free maids that weave their thread with bones

speaker: DUKE ORSINO
text_entry: Do use to chant it: it is silly sooth,

speaker: DUKE ORSINO
text_entry: And dallies with the innocence of love,

speaker: DUKE ORSINO
text_entry: Like the old age.

speaker: Clown
text_entry: Are you ready, sir?

speaker: DUKE ORSINO
text_entry: Ay; prithee, sing.

speaker: DUKE ORSINO
text_entry: Music

speaker: DUKE ORSINO
text_entry: SONG.

speaker: Clown
text_entry: Come away, come away, death,

speaker: Clown
text_entry: And in sad cypress let me be laid;

speaker: Clown
text_entry: Fly away, fly away breath;

speaker: Clown
text_entry: I am slain by a fair cruel maid.

speaker: Clown
text_entry: My shroud of white, stuck all with yew,

speaker: Clown
text_entry: O, prepare it!

speaker: Clown
text_entry: My part of death, no one so true

speaker: Clown
text_entry: Did share it.

speaker: Clown
text_entry: Not a flower, not a flower sweet

speaker: Clown
text_entry: On my black coffin let there be strown;

speaker: Clown
text_entry: Not a friend, not a friend greet

speaker: Clown
text_entry: My poor corpse, where my bones shall be thrown:

speaker: Clown
text_entry: A thousand thousand sighs to save,

speaker: Clown
text_entry: Lay me, O, where

speaker: Clown
text_entry: Sad true lover never find my grave,

speaker: Clown
text_entry: To weep there!

speaker: DUKE ORSINO
text_entry: There's for thy pains.

speaker: Clown
text_entry: No pains, sir: I take pleasure in singing, sir.

speaker: DUKE ORSINO
text_entry: I'll pay thy pleasure then.

speaker: Clown
text_entry: Truly, sir, and pleasure will be paid, one time or another.

speaker: DUKE ORSINO
text_entry: Give me now leave to leave thee.

speaker: Clown
text_entry: Now, the melancholy god protect thee; and the

speaker: Clown
text_entry: tailor make thy doublet of changeable taffeta, for

speaker: Clown
text_entry: thy mind is a very opal. I would have men of such

speaker: Clown
text_entry: constancy put to sea, that their business might be

speaker: Clown
text_entry: every thing and their intent every where; for that's

speaker: Clown
text_entry: it that always makes a good voyage of nothing. Farewell.

speaker: Clown
text_entry: Exit

speaker: DUKE ORSINO
text_entry: Let all the rest give place.

speaker: DUKE ORSINO
text_entry: CURIO and Attendants retire

speaker: DUKE ORSINO
text_entry: Once more, Cesario,

speaker: DUKE ORSINO
text_entry: Get thee to yond same sovereign cruelty:

speaker: DUKE ORSINO
text_entry: Tell her, my love, more noble than the world,

speaker: DUKE ORSINO
text_entry: Prizes not quantity of dirty lands;

speaker: DUKE ORSINO
text_entry: The parts that fortune hath bestow'd upon her,

speaker: DUKE ORSINO
text_entry: Tell her, I hold as giddily as fortune;

speaker: DUKE ORSINO
text_entry: But 'tis that miracle and queen of gems

speaker: DUKE ORSINO
text_entry: That nature pranks her in attracts my soul.

speaker: VIOLA
text_entry: But if she cannot love you, sir?

speaker: DUKE ORSINO
text_entry: I cannot be so answer'd.

speaker: VIOLA
text_entry: Sooth, but you must.

speaker: VIOLA
text_entry: Say that some lady, as perhaps there is,

speaker: VIOLA
text_entry: Hath for your love a great a pang of heart

speaker: VIOLA
text_entry: As you have for Olivia: you cannot love her;

speaker: VIOLA
text_entry: You tell her so; must she not then be answer'd?

speaker: DUKE ORSINO
text_entry: There is no woman's sides

speaker: DUKE ORSINO
text_entry: Can bide the beating of so strong a passion

speaker: DUKE ORSINO
text_entry: As love doth give my heart; no woman's heart

speaker: DUKE ORSINO
text_entry: So big, to hold so much; they lack retention

speaker: DUKE ORSINO
text_entry: Alas, their love may be call'd appetite,

speaker: DUKE ORSINO
text_entry: No motion of the liver, but the palate,

speaker: DUKE ORSINO
text_entry: That suffer surfeit, cloyment and revolt;

speaker: DUKE ORSINO
text_entry: But mine is all as hungry as the sea,

speaker: DUKE ORSINO
text_entry: And can digest as much: make no compare

speaker: DUKE ORSINO
text_entry: Between that love a woman can bear me

speaker: DUKE ORSINO
text_entry: And that I owe Olivia.

speaker: VIOLA
text_entry: Ay, but I know--

speaker: DUKE ORSINO
text_entry: What dost thou know?

speaker: VIOLA
text_entry: Too well what love women to men may owe:

speaker: VIOLA
text_entry: In faith, they are as true of heart as we.

speaker: VIOLA
text_entry: My father had a daughter loved a man,

speaker: VIOLA
text_entry: As it might be, perhaps, were I a woman,

speaker: VIOLA
text_entry: I should your lordship.

speaker: DUKE ORSINO
text_entry: And what's her history?

speaker: VIOLA
text_entry: A blank, my lord. She never told her love,

speaker: VIOLA
text_entry: But let concealment, like a worm i' the bud,

speaker: VIOLA
text_entry: Feed on her damask cheek: she pined in thought,

speaker: VIOLA
text_entry: And with a green and yellow melancholy

speaker: VIOLA
text_entry: She sat like patience on a monument,

speaker: VIOLA
text_entry: Smiling at grief. Was not this love indeed?

speaker: VIOLA
text_entry: We men may say more, swear more: but indeed

speaker: VIOLA
text_entry: Our shows are more than will; for still we prove

speaker: VIOLA
text_entry: Much in our vows, but little in our love.

speaker: DUKE ORSINO
text_entry: But died thy sister of her love, my boy?

speaker: VIOLA
text_entry: I am all the daughters of my father's house,

speaker: VIOLA
text_entry: And all the brothers too: and yet I know not.

speaker: VIOLA
text_entry: Sir, shall I to this lady?

speaker: DUKE ORSINO
text_entry: Ay, that's the theme.

speaker: DUKE ORSINO
text_entry: To her in haste; give her this jewel; say,

speaker: DUKE ORSINO
text_entry: My love can give no place, bide no denay.

speaker: DUKE ORSINO
text_entry: Exeunt

speaker: DUKE ORSINO
text_entry: SCENE V. OLIVIA's garden.

speaker: DUKE ORSINO
text_entry: Enter SIR TOBY BELCH, SIR ANDREW, and FABIAN

speaker: SIR TOBY BELCH
text_entry: Come thy ways, Signior Fabian.

speaker: FABIAN
text_entry: Nay, I'll come: if I lose a scruple of this sport,

speaker: FABIAN
text_entry: let me be boiled to death with melancholy.

speaker: SIR TOBY BELCH
text_entry: Wouldst thou not be glad to have the niggardly

speaker: SIR TOBY BELCH
text_entry: rascally sheep-biter come by some notable shame?

speaker: FABIAN
text_entry: I would exult, man: you know, he brought me out o'

speaker: FABIAN
text_entry: favour with my lady about a bear-baiting here.

speaker: SIR TOBY BELCH
text_entry: To anger him we'll have the bear again; and we will

speaker: SIR TOBY BELCH
text_entry: fool him black and blue: shall we not, Sir Andrew?

speaker: SIR ANDREW
text_entry: An we do not, it is pity of our lives.

speaker: SIR TOBY BELCH
text_entry: Here comes the little villain.

speaker: SIR TOBY BELCH
text_entry: Enter MARIA

speaker: SIR TOBY BELCH
text_entry: How now, my metal of India!

speaker: MARIA
text_entry: Get ye all three into the box-tree: Malvolio's

speaker: MARIA
text_entry: coming down this walk: he has been yonder i' the

speaker: MARIA
text_entry: sun practising behavior to his own shadow this half

speaker: MARIA
text_entry: hour: observe him, for the love of mockery; for I

speaker: MARIA
text_entry: know this letter will make a contemplative idiot of

speaker: MARIA
text_entry: him. Close, in the name of jesting! Lie thou there,

speaker: MARIA
text_entry: Throws down a letter

speaker: MARIA
text_entry: for here comes the trout that must be caught with tickling.

speaker: MARIA
text_entry: Exit

speaker: MARIA
text_entry: Enter MALVOLIO

speaker: MALVOLIO
text_entry: 'Tis but fortune; all is fortune. Maria once told

speaker: MALVOLIO
text_entry: me she did affect me: and I have heard herself come

speaker: MALVOLIO
text_entry: thus near, that, should she fancy, it should be one

speaker: MALVOLIO
text_entry: of my complexion. Besides, she uses me with a more

speaker: MALVOLIO
text_entry: exalted respect than any one else that follows her.

speaker: MALVOLIO
text_entry: What should I think on't?

speaker: SIR TOBY BELCH
text_entry: Here's an overweening rogue!

speaker: FABIAN
text_entry: O, peace! Contemplation makes a rare turkey-cock

speaker: FABIAN
text_entry: of him: how he jets under his advanced plumes!

speaker: SIR ANDREW
text_entry: 'Slight, I could so beat the rogue!

speaker: SIR TOBY BELCH
text_entry: Peace, I say.

speaker: MALVOLIO
text_entry: To be Count Malvolio!

speaker: SIR TOBY BELCH
text_entry: Ah, rogue!

speaker: SIR ANDREW
text_entry: Pistol him, pistol him.

speaker: SIR TOBY BELCH
text_entry: Peace, peace!

speaker: MALVOLIO
text_entry: There is example for't; the lady of the Strachy

speaker: MALVOLIO
text_entry: married the yeoman of the wardrobe.

speaker: SIR ANDREW
text_entry: Fie on him, Jezebel!

speaker: FABIAN
text_entry: O, peace! now he's deeply in: look how

speaker: FABIAN
text_entry: imagination blows him.

speaker: MALVOLIO
text_entry: Having been three months married to her, sitting in

speaker: MALVOLIO
text_entry: my state,--

speaker: SIR TOBY BELCH
text_entry: O, for a stone-bow, to hit him in the eye!

speaker: MALVOLIO
text_entry: Calling my officers about me, in my branched velvet

speaker: MALVOLIO
text_entry: gown; having come from a day-bed, where I have left

speaker: MALVOLIO
text_entry: Olivia sleeping,--

speaker: SIR TOBY BELCH
text_entry: Fire and brimstone!

speaker: FABIAN
text_entry: O, peace, peace!

speaker: MALVOLIO
text_entry: And then to have the humour of state; and after a

speaker: MALVOLIO
text_entry: demure travel of regard, telling them I know my

speaker: MALVOLIO
text_entry: place as I would they should do theirs, to for my

speaker: MALVOLIO
text_entry: kinsman Toby,--

speaker: SIR TOBY BELCH
text_entry: Bolts and shackles!

speaker: FABIAN
text_entry: O peace, peace, peace! now, now.

speaker: MALVOLIO
text_entry: Seven of my people, with an obedient start, make

speaker: MALVOLIO
text_entry: out for him: I frown the while; and perchance wind

speaker: MALVOLIO
text_entry: up watch, or play with my--some rich jewel. Toby

speaker: MALVOLIO
text_entry: approaches; courtesies there to me,--

speaker: SIR TOBY BELCH
text_entry: Shall this fellow live?

speaker: FABIAN
text_entry: Though our silence be drawn from us with cars, yet peace.

speaker: MALVOLIO
text_entry: I extend my hand to him thus, quenching my familiar

speaker: MALVOLIO
text_entry: smile with an austere regard of control,--

speaker: SIR TOBY BELCH
text_entry: And does not Toby take you a blow o' the lips then?

speaker: MALVOLIO
text_entry: Saying, 'Cousin Toby, my fortunes having cast me on

speaker: MALVOLIO
text_entry: your niece give me this prerogative of speech,'--

speaker: SIR TOBY BELCH
text_entry: What, what?

speaker: MALVOLIO
text_entry: 'You must amend your drunkenness.'

speaker: SIR TOBY BELCH
text_entry: Out, scab!

speaker: FABIAN
text_entry: Nay, patience, or we break the sinews of our plot.

speaker: MALVOLIO
text_entry: 'Besides, you waste the treasure of your time with

speaker: MALVOLIO
text_entry: a foolish knight,'--

speaker: SIR ANDREW
text_entry: That's me, I warrant you.

speaker: MALVOLIO
text_entry: 'One Sir Andrew,'--

speaker: SIR ANDREW
text_entry: I knew 'twas I; for many do call me fool.

speaker: MALVOLIO
text_entry: What employment have we here?

speaker: MALVOLIO
text_entry: Taking up the letter

speaker: FABIAN
text_entry: Now is the woodcock near the gin.

speaker: SIR TOBY BELCH
text_entry: O, peace! and the spirit of humour intimate reading

speaker: SIR TOBY BELCH
text_entry: aloud to him!

speaker: MALVOLIO
text_entry: By my life, this is my lady's hand these be her

speaker: MALVOLIO
text_entry: very C's, her U's and her T's and thus makes she her

speaker: MALVOLIO
text_entry: great P's. It is, in contempt of question, her hand.

speaker: SIR ANDREW
text_entry: Her C's, her U's and her T's: why that?

speaker: MALVOLIO
text_entry: [Reads]  'To the unknown beloved, this, and my good

speaker: MALVOLIO
text_entry: wishes:'--her very phrases! By your leave, wax.

speaker: MALVOLIO
text_entry: Soft! and the impressure her Lucrece, with which she

speaker: MALVOLIO
text_entry: uses to seal: 'tis my lady. To whom should this be?

speaker: FABIAN
text_entry: This wins him, liver and all.

speaker: MALVOLIO
text_entry: [Reads]

speaker: MALVOLIO
text_entry: Jove knows I love: But who?

speaker: MALVOLIO
text_entry: Lips, do not move;

speaker: MALVOLIO
text_entry: No man must know.

speaker: MALVOLIO
text_entry: 'No man must know.' What follows? the numbers

speaker: MALVOLIO
text_entry: altered! 'No man must know:' if this should be

speaker: MALVOLIO
text_entry: thee, Malvolio?

speaker: SIR TOBY BELCH
text_entry: Marry, hang thee, brock!

speaker: MALVOLIO
text_entry: [Reads]

speaker: MALVOLIO
text_entry: I may command where I adore;

speaker: MALVOLIO
text_entry: But silence, like a Lucrece knife,

speaker: MALVOLIO
text_entry: With bloodless stroke my heart doth gore:
